sections.title: Introduction — Using a Product Requirement Document (PRD) with GitHub Copilot
sections.summary: Explains the technique of using a PRD to get the best results from GitHub Copilot and introduces the scenario: creating a fake payment server in the sample Lava SAPS environment for integration testing.
key_actions: Describe scenario to Copilot: generate a PRD for a fake payment server
Explain environment (Lava SAPS server with services)

sections.title: Generate the PRD in Visual Studio
sections.summary: Demonstrates copying a 'mega prompt' in Visual Studio and asking Copilot to generate the PRD; shows that generation can take time and that an example PRD is produced.
key_actions: Copy mega prompt in Visual Studio
Ask Copilot to generate the PRD
Wait for Copilot to complete generation
Inspect generated PRD content (dates, scope, proposed features)

sections.title: PRD added to repository and prepare implementation (coding agent mode)
sections.summary: Confirms the PRD was added to the GitHub repository and switches to Copilot's coding agent mode to implement the PRD in the cloud; navigates to the sample repository and uses the agent panel to instruct Copilot to implement the PRD, which will create a pull request and work in the background.
key_actions: Verify PRD is in GitHub repository
Switch to coding agent mode for cloud implementation
Open sample repository
Use the agent panel to issue instruction: 'implement the PRD'
Allow Copilot/agent to create a pull request and run background tasks

sections.title: Review PRD implementation and generated documentation
sections.summary: Shows that the agent completed the PRD implementation, produced code and accompanying documentation (implementation guide, overview, architecture). Notes the automatic choice of SQLite and intent to switch to SQL Server later.
key_actions: Inspect implementation progress and completion
Open generated documentation/implementation guide
Review architecture and database choice (SQLite chosen by default)
Plan to update database choice to SQL Server (2000/2025 mentioned)

sections.title: Run and test the new checkout/payment service in the app
sections.summary: Demonstrates running the new checkout/payment service: add sample products, view cart, proceed to checkout, and place an order. Notes UI is still using an older layout and app is in demo mode. Confirms the new payment service and new order appear in the system.
key_actions: Start the application with the new payment service
Add two sample products to cart
Open cart and click 'proceed to checkout'
Fill required info and place the order
Observe demo mode and UI/layout mismatches
Locate the newly created order in the UI

sections.title: Trace the transaction in Aspire and return to developer mode
sections.summary: Uses Aspire traces to filter for the payment service, showing end-to-end traceability from front end to back end to the payment service. Concludes by switching back to Copilot developer mode to make needed changes.
key_actions: Open Aspire traces
Filter traces for payment service
Inspect trace showing frontend -> backend -> payment service calls
Confirm traceability
Switch back to Copilot developer mode to implement fixes

main_topics: Using Copilot coding agent mode to implement features
Automated pull request creation and background implementation
Database choices (SQLite default, plan to move to SQL Server)
Running and testing a payment/checkout service
Tracing requests with Aspire for end-to-end observability
Switching between agent/cloud mode and developer mode
